headline: Durham police say human remains belong to Kandis Fitzpatrick
author: Simran Singh
sentences: In an update Wednesday morning, Durham Regional Police say that in July, while Strong was incarcerated, he offered up information about the location of Fitzpatrick’s body.
On Nov. 14, partial remains were sent to the Office of the Chief Coroner and forensic testing and DNA identified them as those belonging to Kandis Fitzpatrick.

On Nov. 4, Durham police say investigators then began searching the treeline in a green space near Secreto Drive and Britannia Avenue East in Oshawa.
Human remains discovered in Oshawa in November are those of a woman Adam Strong was convicted of killing last year, said Durham police.
Strong was convicted in mid-March 2021 of manslaughter in Fitzpatrick’s death and first degree murder of another woman, Rori Hache.
When asked by reporters at the news conference, Durham police said Strong’s motive for disclosing the information was unclear.
Fitzpatrick’s body was never recovered, but DNA found during the investigation linked Strong to Fitzpatrick.
“There was no financial compensation or no added privilege for him while in custody,” Durham police added.

Strong had told staff at the correctional facility, who then turned the information over to police.
Forensic crews found human remains several days later on Nov. 8.
The update was livestreamed on the Durham police facebook page.
Kandis Fitzpatrick was 19 when she went missing in 2008.
